review_title: Some maybe get it real good but BCGEU staff is treated poorly
job_title: Prefer To Remain Anonymous in New Westminster, BC
pros: Location, campus facilities, 7-hour workday. Some good people working at Douglas who are making the difference for students and our community.
cons: If you are considering a job offer and you see that the job is BCGEU staff, beware. Faculty and administrators have a much better deal compared to BCGEU members. Outrageous inequality. 1) Their staff salaries are already considerably lower than the market because of the Collective Agreement, and you will be offered the lowest salary they can offer. 2) Their "defined pension" depends on your salary and will be directly impacted by your low income. After many-many-many years of contributing 8.5% of your salary (mandatory), upon retirement you will be given a pension that is proportionate to your salary. I am not saying that municipal pension is bad but it is not a miracle. 3) The union is very passive in protecting members' interests. HR refuses to address concerns and sends staff back to the union. You end up in a cycle where you are not properly represented. 4) Although there are still some caring managers and some good leaders, the environment became worse in the past three years after some changes in senior management. The politics sometimes are simply sickening. The interpretation of procedures varies case by case. Favoritism flourishes. A lot of good leaders and good professionals have left Douglas College. Some incompetent folks have been promoted. You did this to yourself.

review_title: Fantastic workplace and sense of community

job_title: Regular Faculty in New Westminster, BC
pros: Work experiences vary a great deal between staff, faculty and management and between divisions and departments. At its best you can find a reasonably paid job with considerable autonomy and interest, no micro management and OK benefits and pension. The Union environment protects faculty and staff, to some extent, from random acts of management. Although teaching workload is moderately high, regular faculty have a non teaching semester to catch up on scholarly work and do course prep. Bureaucracy isn't really that bad compared to many large organizations.
cons: If you read the other reviews you will find that some other employees (mainly staff and contract workers) have bad experiences. Pay is lower for staff who have lower status and influence than faculty (as in most post secondary institutions). It is not an entrepreneurial environment although there are pockets of innovation. It's also not a particularly rewarding environment for middle managers (Deans, Directors etc) who have formal responsibility but little real authority or influence over many decisions (but do get decent pay). Bureaucracy is getting a bit worse. Some students seem to be getting a bit more disrespectful. In some departments there is a 'teach and run' culture of minimal involvement.

review_title: A perfect place to start your career
job_title: Program Assistant I in New Westminster, BC
pros: Supportive environment, well-connected team, professional development, advancement opportunities, excellent resources
cons: use of personal equipment is sometimes needed (Pandemic Problem)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Westminster, BC
pros: Just knowing what Douglas is like in terms of community, work-life balance, perks and culture, I was surprised to see a number of really negative reviews here. But turns out it’s just one area whereas being a part of Douglas means having secure employment with nice people around you and sense of purpose in your work life. You will be a part of the community of educators contributing to someone’s learning. What can be better than having a meaningful career? Besides that, you get extended benefits, pension, free access to gym and library, ongoing opportunities for professional development (lots of seminars and training sessions offered here!), and smart people to learn from. When people ask where I work I am proud to say it’s Douglas.
cons: Douglas is a large public organization which means career advancement is limited. If you want to be promoted, you have to serve your time and make sure you constantly acquire new marketable skills. If you lack required credentials or leadership training/experience, you will not be given a more advanced role just because you are already here. With good reputation, they get enough external interest in vacancies to be able not to tolerate lack of qualifications.

review_title: Great Place To Work - So many Extras
job_title: Anonymous in New Westminster, BC
pros: There are so many different types of jobs that you can try and move around to which helps people to grow and learn.  Things like education tuition waivers, great vacation, benefits and pension plan, a super healthy union/employer relationship, as well as loads of workplace perks and extras (on-site gym with lunchtime classes, on-site daycare to name a few).  There are additional stat holiday days off that have been bargained which are a bonus days you don't need to book as vacation (Easter Monday, Christmas Eve, New Years Eve) as well as events such as an annual end of Summer BBQ, Professional Development Days, holiday movie viewings, and holiday parties.  There are College-Wide Halloween costume competitions, group movie nights, and opportunities to give back to the community.  Douglas really does make sure their employees feel they are valued and important.  They have been one of BC's Top 100 Employers for several years in a row, and people who work here stick around for a long time.  It's hard to find another work place with the same types of benefits and culture.
cons: Just being in a unionized environment creates some restrictions, but nothing too negative.  There is always support from HR and the Union to navigate these things.

job_title: Program Assistant II in Coquitlam, BC
pros: friendly work environment. I enjoyed working there
cons: no cons. I left because I have to relocate to another city

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Maple Ridge, BC
pros: - staff members knowledgeable and supportive of one another
cons:
- If you like micromanagement and being reminded that you are 'inferior' to management then enjoy...
- The lack of transparency and support given to staff is horrid. I have never seen anyone micro manage and mismanage a staff so terribly, and speak in such a condescending tone -- yet when it comes time to actually support your staff members and encourage unity, she locks her self away in her office.
- Assumed rumors and feedback about Maple Ridge office were exaggerated; they are nothing in comparison to experiencing it. On the plus side, watching staff members leave and find jobs that aren't necessarily better has been nice, because it validates a simple saying -- 'people don't leave bad jobs, they leave bad managers.'

job_title: Admissions Officer in New Westminster, BC
pros:
Flexible work environment - some depts offer flex days
Great team / great coworkers
Good benefits
Great starting pay - but increases are next to nothing
Can attend free work out sessions for your lunch break
Shifts are 8-4 most departments M-F
Fantastic OT (when offered)
Event potlucks! Spring lunch! Christmas Party! Very good team.
cons:
Low pay compared to other institutions
Increases for promotions and higher level of responsibility hardly seem worth it 
Senior management grandfathered in, out of touch with today's world
Difficult to become "permanent" and get vacation time off
Low opportunity to move up - jobs written for others
Hard to switch departments even if qualified (see above)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Westminster, BC

cons: So much red tape to go through to put forward any change. Very difficult to move up in the company .Management doesn't like to promote from within. Way too many managers, not enough staff. A severe shake up in Upper Management needed before to get back the good atmosphere that use to be here. It has become a very stressful place to work.

job_title: Student Assistant in Coquitlam, BC

- Treated as a human being first and foremost.

- They train you to be prepared for the workplace once you graduate.
